quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Getting promoted is way harder if you're not good in telling stories and rallying the team behind the shared goal and all these kind of things, and you usually achieve this through good storytelling techniques.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Connects career progression directly to storytelling as a practical leadership skill for aligning teams.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And in some teams, I've seen the product person not being really, really good at it, but then the whole team helped creating these stories and stuff like this.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive lever: teams can partially compensate for a PM’s weaker storytelling through collective narrative-building.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So you definitely could compensate to some extent, but I would consider it a bit of a career staller if you don't get to a decent level of storytelling and to a decent level of public speaking.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Frames storytelling and public speaking as baseline competencies—optional early, but limiting long-term if neglected.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we focus on three things.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a simple three-part structure that can be used to frame learning goals or coaching agendas.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Well, based on our data, about a third of people will consider switching to another company after just one bad experience during onboarding.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: A concrete retention risk data point that quantifies how costly onboarding/CSV import failures can be.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I've consistently seen that improving onboarding is one of the highest leverage opportunities for both signup conversion and increasing long-term retention. Getting people to your aha moment more quickly and reliably is so incredibly important.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical prioritization heuristic: treat onboarding speed-to-aha as a top-leverage product investment.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Plus, how should you help people grow if you have no clue what their role actually is all about?
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A blunt coaching principle: managers must understand the craft of product to effectively develop product people.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And then I use this metaphor of the eight-legged creature because people tend to talk about T-shaped employee profiles, but T-shaped is so not enough for a product person, right?
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reframes PM competency as multi-dimensional rather than “T-shaped.”

quotes.topic_title: Petra’s coaching work and impact
quotes.text: How I usually describe it is that I work with people leading product people, so that's the product leadership level that I'm looking at.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Clarifies her coaching focus as product leaders (leaders of PMs), a useful framing for who leadership coaching is for.

quotes.topic_title: Petra’s coaching work and impact
quotes.text: So in one-on-one coachings, that's what I know. I coached around 130 people so far over the last few years, which is already a lot. Most of them have, yeah, 10 to 20 sessions with me. Some really stick with me over the years so they have more sessions.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Gives concrete scale and an implicit cadence/commitment model (10–20 sessions) for effective 1:1 coaching.

quotes.topic_title: Petra’s coaching work and impact
quotes.text: And then I have group coaching sessions and corporate and then public setups. And that's, I would say, another 150.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Highlights a multi-modal coaching approach (1:1 plus group/corporate/public) and quantifies additional reach.

quotes.topic_title: Petra’s coaching work and impact
quotes.text: So usually, those people are working with a team of 10 product people and there are some ripple effects.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Introduces the “ripple effects” mental model: coaching leaders scales impact through their teams.

quotes.topic_title: Petra’s coaching work and impact
quotes.text: And in the end, yeah, I did a bit of the math and I think it might be around 50,000, 60,000 people.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A memorable quantified estimate of downstream impact, reinforcing the leverage of coaching product leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Why middle-layer product leaders matter
quotes.text: Which I feel like is often the most important and influential layer of a company because they're the ones doing a lot of the work at making a lot of the decisions day to day.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical org-design insight: first-line product leaders have outsized day-to-day impact compared to more senior layers.

quotes.topic_title: Why middle-layer product leaders matter
quotes.text: Plus, at least with a lot of clients that I'm working with, they are not trained product people.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Calls out a common root cause behind weak product leadership: many managers of PMs never learned product fundamentals.

quotes.topic_title: Why middle-layer product leaders matter
quotes.text: So they often come from a marketing background, or a business background, or from the data background, so to say, or the engineering background, but they often never have worked in a product management role.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Gives a concrete pattern practitioners can watch for when diagnosing capability gaps in product leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Why middle-layer product leaders matter
quotes.text: So they're missing a lot of basic product management practice and a lot of empathy for the struggle of the product people to some extent.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Actionable coaching focus: build both product craft and empathy to better support PMs.

quotes.topic_title: Why middle-layer product leaders matter
quotes.text: Plus, how should you help people grow if you have no clue what their role actually is all about?
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A memorable principle for leadership development: you can’t effectively coach a role you don’t understand.

quotes.topic_title: Common gaps for non-product product leaders
quotes.text: Because as the line manager has no clue about the product community out there and the craftless product management, they often struggle to point them in the right direction to say, "Hey, I think that's a problem somebody else already had. So maybe you could watch a talk or read this blog post or there's a book about this particular thing and then go try it."
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable coaching gap: non-product leaders fail to curate external product-community learning to accelerate PM growth.

quotes.topic_title: Common gaps for non-product product leaders
quotes.text: So product people IC level often have done to learn a lot of things on their own, so to say, because nobody's curating their progression for them to some extent.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Points to a systemic development issue—IC PMs are left to self-teach due to lack of structured progression support.

quotes.topic_title: Common gaps for non-product product leaders
quotes.text: And then I use this metaphor of the eight-legged creature because people tend to talk about T-shaped employee profiles, but T-shaped is so not enough for a product person, right?
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable mental model that challenges the common “T-shaped” framing for PM skill requirements.

quotes.topic_title: Common gaps for non-product product leaders
quotes.text: You can read all the books, you can take all the courses, you can read my newsletter, you can read your book, which we'll talk about, but there's only so far you'll get without actually just doing it and just failing, doing great things that succeed.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Emphasizes experiential learning as the limiting factor in PM development—practice and failure are required, not just theory.

quotes.topic_title: Common gaps for non-product product leaders
quotes.text: I so often have said the sentence of, it's not a role, it's a career being in product and, really, there's so many things to learn and so many things to get good at.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Reframes product management as a long-term career craft, setting expectations for continuous learning and skill accumulation.

quotes.topic_title: Petra’s book: Strong Product People
quotes.text: It's quite a niche book, right? So it's focusing on people managing product people, so product leads and then the people development part of their job.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Clarifies the book’s target audience and frames product leadership as primarily people development, not just product work.

quotes.topic_title: Petra’s book: Strong Product People
quotes.text: So it's not another book talking about how to come up with a great product strategy.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Challenges the common emphasis on strategy by signaling a different focus area for product leaders: coaching and development.

quotes.topic_title: Petra’s book: Strong Product People
quotes.text: So it's not so much about how you do these things on your own, it's more how you could help product people to understand hypothesis-driven product discovery a bit more, or how could you help them think about team motivation, or how could you help them get better and giving feedback, all these kind of things.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Provides a practical coaching-oriented lens for product leadership, naming specific capability areas to develop in PMs.

quotes.topic_title: Petra’s book: Strong Product People
quotes.text: So this book has this meta level of helping product leads to develop their product folks.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Introduces a “meta level” mental model: the leader’s job is enabling others’ product skills rather than doing the work themselves.

quotes.topic_title: Five ingredients to coach PMs well
quotes.text: And number one is really having a solid definition of what a good product person looks like in your context. So what is your definition of good, so to say?
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: She starts her coaching framework by insisting leaders explicitly define what “good” means for PMs in their specific environment.

quotes.topic_title: Five ingredients to coach PMs well
quotes.text: So what is the next bigger challenge I would love to assign this product person to if I could because I know that would help them to learn a new skill or to, yeah, again, you know how, whatever it is, right? And creating such a list once a quarter, for example, you block yourself an hour in your calendar, you write down the names of your direct reports, and then you just think about, "Okay, what would be this next bigger challenge for them?"
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable practice for systematically identifying growth opportunities for each PM on a quarterly cadence.

quotes.topic_title: Five ingredients to coach PMs well
quotes.text: Then it's definitely a development plan, but I think that's more on them than it is on you because you don't get the apps from other people's branches.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A memorable reminder that managers can support development, but ownership and execution must stay with the PM.

quotes.topic_title: Five ingredients to coach PMs well
quotes.text: ask them how they want to be reminded of the personal development and how you could help them and the system while doing that because they still have a day job, right? So the development will never be the number one priority, and it shouldn't.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Practical guidance for tailoring follow-up and setting realistic expectations that development competes with day-to-day work.

quotes.topic_title: Where to start: development plans and follow-up
quotes.text: No, I usually advise people to start with the development plan because even if you have never done the assessment and even if you don't have your compass, your definition of what makes a good product manager, you usually have an idea or they have an idea of what they want to learn next or where they want to get better at.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Practical starting point for managers: begin with a PM-owned development plan even without a formal competency framework.

quotes.topic_title: Where to start: development plans and follow-up
quotes.text: And then it's obviously the follow-up that makes a big difference and that just takes so little time from the product lead, the small notches, that's super easy.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Emphasizes that lightweight, consistent follow-up is the high-leverage part of coaching and development.

quotes.topic_title: Where to start: development plans and follow-up
quotes.text: And these development plans, I usually tell people to create a new one with a new headline or topic once a quarter or every four months.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Gives a concrete cadence for refreshing development plans to keep growth focused without heavy process.

quotes.topic_title: Where to start: development plans and follow-up
quotes.text: So that is something where I usually say, "No, start with your own personal team because the folks in your team usually just have you as a line manager. So grade your compass and encourage your peers to grade their compass and, a bit down the line, it might make sense to harmonize some of that, but it's better to start helping your product folks and giving them some orientation than being totally paralyzed by the fact that it's not a compass that is used in the whole company."
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Counteracts waiting for company-wide alignment by advocating a team-first competency “compass” to avoid paralysis.

quotes.topic_title: Where to start: development plans and follow-up
quotes.text: Something that I did with my PMs that was so effective was every time we did a performance review, every six months, we had a performance review, we put together a Google Doc with all of the things that we agree they should be working on and we pick, say, five themes or three themes, and then we pick very concrete things they should do over the next six months that will help them develop these things.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific, repeatable mechanism (review doc + themes + concrete actions) for turning performance reviews into development plans.

quotes.topic_title: Defining competent PMs: ladders, traits, assessments
quotes.text: I'd say use one of the assessments that are already out there.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: She advises teams without a solid PM ladder to start from existing competency assessments rather than inventing from scratch.

quotes.topic_title: Defining competent PMs: ladders, traits, assessments
quotes.text: Go find one that is close to what you actually think a good PM should look like and then customize it.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A practical method: pick a near-fit framework and tailor it to your company’s definition of PM excellence.

quotes.topic_title: Defining competent PMs: ladders, traits, assessments
quotes.text: Don't use it just by copy paste because sometimes you have just rather technical PMs in your organization and then all these assessment points about user interviews and discovery are maybe not that applicable in your situation, right?
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A counterpoint to generic competency models: what matters depends on the PM role mix (e.g., technical PMs).

quotes.topic_title: Defining competent PMs: ladders, traits, assessments
quotes.text: Plus, reflecting on the personality traits because I think there are some things that you better hire for and that are super hard to develop in a corporate environment.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: She highlights a hiring-first approach for traits that are difficult to coach later, complementing skills-based assessments.

quotes.topic_title: Defining competent PMs: ladders, traits, assessments
quotes.text: So for me, that, for example, is curiosity.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: She names a specific high-leverage trait to screen for when hiring product people.

quotes.topic_title: PMwheel framework overview
quotes.text: So I split all the things that PMs usually do in eight buckets, so to say.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Introduces the PMwheel as a structured, comprehensive skills framework for product managers.

quotes.topic_title: PMwheel framework overview
quotes.text: And then last, but not least, it's agile because when I was still coaching PMs, I often found that they never reflected on the underlying basics of agile ways of working. So they often never heard about the agile manifesto, or agile values, or agile principles, no matter what framework they're using. But I think that is key.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that many PMs use agile rituals without understanding agile fundamentals—and that gap matters.

quotes.topic_title: PMwheel framework overview
quotes.text: And every of those buckets comes with at least 15 framing questions.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Makes the framework operational by turning each competency area into concrete assessment prompts.

quotes.topic_title: PMwheel framework overview
quotes.text: And I usually advise people to do a self-assessment, then ask their line management for an assessment, and ideally some of your team members because they have a different perspective on you as a product management personality as well.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Actionable coaching method: triangulate growth areas using self, manager, and team perspectives.

quotes.topic_title: PMwheel framework overview
quotes.text: And then that's why I created the PMwheel to have these first conversations about where they think we should invest more time in our coaching sessions.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Shows how to use the PMwheel as a “compass” to quickly focus coaching on the highest-leverage areas.

quotes.topic_title: Practical coaching: questions and 1:1 structure
quotes.text: One easy tip is get yourself a list of great questions that you could ask in one on ones if you don't have the time to prepare.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A practical tactic to improve 1:1s even when you’re busy: keep a ready-to-use question bank.

quotes.topic_title: Practical coaching: questions and 1:1 structure
quotes.text: So maybe it's really something like explaining them the Eisenhower matrix for getting better time management because they never heard about anything that could help them prioritize their tasks because that's the reality that we find in a lot of the companies, right?
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Highlights that “small,” foundational tools can be the highest-leverage coaching for PMs who lack practical basics.

quotes.topic_title: Practical coaching: questions and 1:1 structure
quotes.text: I think two weeks ago, one of my coaches told me that he stopped reading a lot of books and consuming a lot of content and he instead dedicates the whole year to using one methodology or book.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A counterintuitive learning approach: depth over breadth by committing to one method for a full year.

quotes.topic_title: Practical coaching: questions and 1:1 structure
quotes.text: So it really focuses on incremental improvements, not crazy stressing everybody out improvements, not, "What could I do to make it a 10?" It's more really, "How could I improve your situation? Really build rapport, really be there for your product folks.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Captures the Mochary-style scaling mindset: aim for small step-ups to build trust and momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Practical coaching: questions and 1:1 structure
quotes.text: So that, for example, is something that I always have handy. And if I have this notion of, "Okay, this person maybe really needs a hack to some extent," then this conversation about, "Hey, look, there is this list of 30 emotions, where do you think you currently add and why and could I help you with that?"
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A concrete 1:1 technique to unlock harder conversations: use an emotions list to help people name how they feel.

quotes.topic_title: Storytelling basics: time investment and human language
quotes.text: Often totally underestimate how many time actually great storytellers are investing in creating the stories and making sure they can share the story in nice ways and formats. So that's maybe the first tip, you have to plan to put in a lot of work to create your story.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Reframes storytelling as a deliberate craft that requires planned effort, not a natural talent you either have or don’t.

quotes.topic_title: Storytelling basics: time investment and human language
quotes.text: Then I think that's two weeks of work, not eight hours a day, obviously, but two weeks of work, maybe one or two hours a day to really carve that story and think about different audiences and different framings of, when am I able to tell the story?
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Gives a concrete rule-of-thumb time investment and a practical focus (audiences + framings) for a quarterly narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Storytelling basics: time investment and human language
quotes.text: So you have to practice and you have to put in a lot of work and time to come up with a logical, compelling, motivating story that then lasts for longer than a week or two.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Emphasizes repetition and iteration as the mechanism for producing durable narratives that align teams beyond a single meeting.

quotes.topic_title: Storytelling basics: time investment and human language
quotes.text: And then the other tip would be really make sure that you're using language that speaks to the heart and the minds of the people because we constantly tend to use too much of our business lingo and it's banner blindness.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Introduces “banner blindness” as a mental model for why jargon stops landing—and why human language is essential for impact.

quotes.topic_title: Storytelling basics: time investment and human language
quotes.text: So you could talk about smell, and sense, and how people feel, and how their life would be better if this product would be out, all these kind of things.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Offers a concrete technique: use sensory and emotional specifics to make product narratives vivid and motivating.

quotes.topic_title: Public speaking: practice, feedback, and nerves
quotes.text: And so the easiest way is to get in front of really small and super friendly audiences.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A practical starting strategy for building public-speaking confidence by lowering stakes and increasing psychological safety.

quotes.topic_title: Public speaking: practice, feedback, and nerves
quotes.text: So really start small and then grow the audience over time and always make sure, because that helped me a lot, to get feedback from strangers and peers if possible.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A stepwise improvement loop: gradually increase audience size while systematically collecting feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Public speaking: practice, feedback, and nerves
quotes.text: Because the peers tend to give you the harsher critique, so to say, where the strangers are more polite, but they're not so familiar with the work you do or with the story that you want to tell so they can spot some gaps in your storytelling technique or something like that.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A nuanced feedback model that highlights complementary strengths of peer vs. stranger feedback for improving talks.

quotes.topic_title: Public speaking: practice, feedback, and nerves
quotes.text: And again, friendly faces front row. So find people that you like and respect and that you know have the spark in their eyes when you start talking. That definitely helps as well.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable tactic to manage nerves and boost confidence by anchoring on supportive audience members.

quotes.topic_title: Public speaking: practice, feedback, and nerves
quotes.text: Yes, backstage. You're doing those ones backstage. And think about what you're wearing because if you're wearing something like that and do this before you enter the stage, people might see that.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Operational guidance for using pre-talk anxiety techniques discreetly and avoiding unintended audience distraction.

quotes.topic_title: Career impact of storytelling and role models
quotes.text: Can do the IC level product management job, but getting promoted is way harder if you're not good in telling stories and rallying the team behind the shared goal and all these kind of things.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Connects storytelling skill directly to promotion difficulty, highlighting it as a key leadership lever beyond core IC execution.

quotes.topic_title: Career impact of storytelling and role models
quotes.text: And you usually achieve this through good storytelling techniques.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Points to storytelling as a learnable set of techniques rather than an innate talent, implying a practical skill-building path.

quotes.topic_title: Career impact of storytelling and role models
quotes.text: So you definitely could compensate to some extent, but I would consider it a bit of a career solo if you don't get to decent level of storytelling and to a decent level of public speaking.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Offers a nuanced, slightly contrarian view: teams can compensate, but there’s still a career ceiling without baseline storytelling/speaking competence.

quotes.topic_title: Career impact of storytelling and role models
quotes.text: And he was really the first person who entered every stage that he could find to talk about the things that he wants to achieve with us as a product team and as a product organization.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Provides a concrete role-model behavior—proactively taking every speaking opportunity to align and motivate the org around product goals.

quotes.topic_title: Career impact of storytelling and role models
quotes.text: But he gave great TED Talks, really data-heavy TED Talks because they often hear from product people, yeah, but the work we do that's so boring, how could we make a great story out of that? And I think Hans Rosling showed over and over again that you can.
quotes.speaker: Petra Wille
quotes.context: Counters the common belief that data-heavy/product work can’t be compelling, pointing to a proven example of making “boring” material engaging through storytelling.
